Subject: Re: [neat] HyperNEAT: Creating Neural Networks with CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=yFye2jySPqeseXhoUoQAiXe5vIdfcc4sX0W9zT9cVualnQKgvQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: ian_badcoe

Hi,
	Can I add my opinion to the other's saying that from what I read so 
far, the idea of HyperNEAT is brilliant.

	Having said that (always got to balance the praise and criticism) I 
do feel that there is a little something that has been missed in this 
particular approach.  I really meant to say something before, way 
back when you posted the "Patterns without development" work that 
preceded this.

	What I am getting at, is the difference between a function mapping, 
however complex, and an iterative system.  This difference seems to 
me to be a fairly crucial factor in the nature of developmental biology.

	The reason this difference matters is something I touched on before:

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/message/1818

	albeit only "touched" on it.

	I am having some difficulty justifying this position, partly because 
I haven't been near the literature on any of this for over a year, 
partly because it is quite a deep point about evolvability, and 
partly because it is by no means proven, intuitive and a quantitative 
difference rather than a qualitative one, however:

	FIRST let me illustrate the sort of iterative system that I 
mean.  What I am referring to is (say) something like your 4D 
connection density function (substrate configuration, I think you 
called it).  Some sort of field, probably discretised into cells for 
convenience of computation, with some value(s) stored on each cell.

	NOW, the difference in the two approaches is that using CPPNs, all 
we will do is evaluate one function (possibly very complex) once, for 
each cell in the field.

	BUT for an iterative approach, we will probably fill the field in 
that manner as a start state, but after that we will then iterate 
over it N times applying some sort of rule to update the field on 
each pass.  It is the fact that the rules act on the output of 
previous stages that gives the system its power.  Rules could be 
targeted in various ways and have various effects, but we can imagine 
the general case of recognizing some pattern (either of values in a 
single cell, or else relative values in a locality of cells) and 
changing some values in a cell as a result.

	In BIOLOGY, this equates to real cells.  Every cell contains the 
same genes but not all genes are activated.  The embryo starts with a 
simple polarity (up-down) defined by a chemical gradient.  Genes are 
activated at certain places based on the amount of chemical and the 
gene-products produce other chemicals.  Some chemicals also leak from 
cell to cell.  Thus simple patterns of chemicals become more complex 
because genes essentially "pattern recognize" certain areas in the 
organism, and start producing other chemicals in response.

	The power of a system like this is, if (say) the number of legs 
changes (by changing the number of repeats of a pattern at an early 
stage in the process), then the later stages still have a reasonable 
chance of doing something sane even though the basic plan has 
changed.  The process that would wire nerves and blood to N legs, 
works (almost) as happily with N+2 legs.  This is why two headed 
snakes are alive (if unfit) but two nosed Boeing 747's are scrap.

	[[I have spoken about this before, and in fact I wrote (most of) a 
complex philosophical web-page (called "the Manifesto for Evolving 
Agents") which went into this in some depth.  Maybe I'll see if I can 
get that up on the web somewhere, even unfinished, and the community 
might give me some useful feedback on it and get me working again.

	Anyway, as you can imagine, an iterative development system is an 
order of magnitude more complex than HyperNEAT, and strays into all 
out usual areas of interest/difficulty such as modularity etc.  Which 
is why HyperNEAT is so clever as an intermediate step.  Nice one Ken!

	Ian
